keyTakeAways: The Pentagon, under Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and Deputy Steve Feinberg, introduced new memos requiring all military officials to obtain prior approval from the legislative affairs office before engaging with Congress.
This policy shift appears to be part of a broader effort by Hegseth to tighten control over how military communications are managed and presented to lawmakers.
The move follows the departure of most Pentagon reporters, suggesting a strategic retreat from direct reporting and a desire for centralized control of messaging.
The Pentagon claims the policy is 'pragmatic' and aims to improve communication accuracy and transparency, though it raises concerns about reduced responsiveness and access to real-time information.
A second memo formed a working group to further define legislative engagement procedures, indicating ongoing policy development within the department.
The new rules may undermine the independence of individual military branches and limit the flow of timely information to Congress, potentially affecting legislative oversight and public trust.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and Deputy Steve Feinberg issued two memos in late October 2025 requiring Pentagon officials—including the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff—to obtain prior approval from the legislative affairs office before communicating with Congress. This marks a significant shift from previous practices, where individual agencies managed their own communications. The move comes after most Pentagon reporters left the building, and appears to be part of a broader effort by Hegseth to exert tighter control over messaging. While Pentagon leadership frames the policy as a 'pragmatic step' to improve accuracy and transparency, critics may see it as reducing responsiveness and access to real-time information. A second memo established a working group to further define legislative engagement rules, signaling ongoing policy development. These changes raise concerns about transparency, independence, and the impact on congressional oversight of military affairs.
title: Pentagon Imposes New Rules on Congressional Communications After Reporters Leave
